page.title: 01SNOWSHILL IN GLOUCESTERSHIRE
page.content: This has always been an agricultural district although there is some woodland. Barley, wheat and sprouts are the main crops but the area is best known for sheep which have grazed on these hills since time immemorial. At the north of the block lies the oolitic limestone village of Snowshill which consists of the manor house, the pub, the village hall, the post office and houses and cottages clustered around the village green and the church. In the 1086 Domesday the population was about 80 and now it is approxiamtely 150. Snowshill has always been a farming community and this is still true although inevitably others have moved in and a few cottages have become holiday homes. The mainly sixteenth and seventeenth century Snowshill Manir, belonging to the National Trust, attracts visitors
